newsitem.title: JAPAN: TIFFE euroyen slightly up following stocks' fall.
newsitem.headline: TIFFE euroyen slightly up following stocks' fall.

text.p: Key December three-month euroyen deposit rate futures on TIFFE were slightly firmer at midday on Tuesday following a fall in Tokyo stocks and bank merger news.
The December ended the morning up 0.02 at 99.07. Turnover was 22,316.
"Euroyen futures rose following the Nikkei's fall. However, most players were unwilling to trade actively before the release of the BOJ's 'tankan'," said a city bank trader.
At midday, the Nikkei 225 stock average was down 361.64 points, or 2.01 percent, at 17,641.76, after falling as low as 17,529.05.
Hokkaido Takushoku Bank and Hokkaido Bank said on Tuesday they plan to merge in April 1998.
Meanwhile, Nippon Credit Bank (NCB) said its three non-bank financial affiliates had filed for bankruptcy at the Tokyo District Court.
The assorted news was positive for euroyen futures, underscoring the lingering problem of Japan's financial system, traders said.
Market participants, however, were cautious ahead of the release of the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) key quarterly "tankan" corporate survey on Wednesday, traders said.
The December's gains were pared on profit-taking after it hit an intraday high of 99.10, as the key unsecured overnight call rate failed to fall substantially on Tuesday morning, traders said.
The BOJ injected 400 billion yen into the money market on Tuesday morning, supplying 300 billion yen more than the market needed to offset a fund shortfall for the second consecutive day.
The overnight call rate was traded at 0.55 percent shortly after the BOJ operation, but rose to 0.65 percent by late morning, money traders said.
Fiscal year-end fund demand pushed the weighted average of the overnight rate to 0.72 percent on Monday, the highest level since September 1995.
Banks' preference for short-term funds was responsible for the higher overnight rate, traders said.
No new certificates of deposit (CDs) were issued on Tuesday morning. One-, two- and three-month CDs were all offered at 0.55 percent.
